title: Is it possible to hide the cursor in a webpage using CSS or Javascript?
body:
Pointer Lock API

While the cursor: none CSS solution is definitely a solid and easy workaround, if your actual goal is to remove the default cursor while your web application is being used, and instead implement your own interpretation of raw mouse movement (or ignore it), you might want to consider using the Pointer Lock API instead.

This will actually remove the cursor, and not just hide it while it is hovering certain elements in your webapp. In layman's terms, you won't be able to move it outside the browser area to make it appear again, as all mouse movement is effectively intercepted by your code. You'll need to programmatically enable the cursor for it to be visible again.

To lock the cursor, you can use requestPointerLock:

document.body.requestPointerLock();

Note: This API call can only be made in response to direct user-interaction, such as a click. Modern browsers supporting this feature will prompt the user for a confirmation before the lock is engaged.

To release the lock, you can use exitPointerLock:

document.exitPointerLock();
